Hello Almost Red! - great rock tune!  The guitar work reminds me of ZZ Top (that should be taken as a compliment) and the vocals are very well done, and with a touch of humour. Hi guys - firstly thank you for letting me hear your music. I really appreciate it. 
Where do I start with this one? It's certainly quirky and a load of fun. I don't know why I had Je Suis Un Rock Star in my head whilst listening - is that a good thing? Perhaps.
Even though the song is awful, you do find yourself singing along which I guess is what all artists want - to get people singing your tunes!
Saying that however, the music industry has moved on a little from novelty singles - apart from around Christmas and then all bets are off.  
I'm not sure I can do anything with this one from my end. Unfortunately it isn't the sort of release our station would play. 
I do wish you the best of luck with everything. i will keep tabs on your new releases as it is going to be interesting to see where you go with it. All the best, Beefy

The folk sound with catchy choruses turns this record into a good one to play everywhere, anytime.

Hello Rock A La Carte, thank you for the track So much better (together).

There is no doubting the pop sensibility of this track nor it's catchiness.

For my personal preference in music it's way more pure pop than what I would ever listen to though.  I feel this may appeal to daytime radio fans who perhaps favour clean cut country music.  I actually feel this would do really well soundtracking a childrens TV show of some kind.

I love the energy and passion and I commend the fund raising, but not one for me I'm afraid.

All the best for 2021.

'So Much Better' is a fun project and also great to see these guys helping out a charity.
Unfortunately not quite a fit with our station, but we do wish you the best of luck with the song.
p.s Yes, awesome guitar solo indeed!

Hi¬† Mehari :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Fame to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Fame and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
So Fame definitely left us feeling like a good time was had. It's got plenty of groove, it's dripping with strong 80s-pop inspired vocal performances reminding us of modern bands like HAIM who do this kind of throwback indiepop-synthpop well. You honestly have produced and performed one of the most polished examples of this we've been sent in a while, so congratulations! The breakdown in the 2nd minute leading to that final build up and chorus was great.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, it just didn't subvert the expectations away from "regular" commercially successful retropop/throwback synthpop/indiepop formula. This had disco groove vibes that definitely work but that isn't something we actively want on our playlist. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Dear Mehari,

Although "Fame" is a solid production, I felt a few things could have been a bit different; if I may :

a) I felt the vocals were way too loud in the mix. I would have really liked them a bit quieter !
b) Instrumental was on the other hand low in volume, especially in the verses. I would have tried to match the volume of the vocals and turn it down by 1 or 2 db !
c) Last but not least, I would have liked for more upfront drums, especially for a song of your genre !

I'm really sorry I will have to pass on "Fame" for now.
Can't but thank you for your submission and wish you all the success with it !

Hi Darwin, Mainecoon and Jae Joven :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. We're a boutique PR and A&R agency who manage a handful of artists, one of which is Spectoral. He's heavily involved and usually has final say on track adds, but we actually do the bulk of the curation on his behalf here on Soundplate, because Futurepop receives over 100 submissions a week at the moment! Curating this is a labour of love.

We co-curate Futurepop, our main playlist, for both Apple Music and Spotify. This is the one you submitted Your Body¬†to. We look for a specific niche to feature. Futurepop's description reads: "Cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alt-RnB. It's the future of pop, pushing the genre forward." ¬†

Here are the links to follow Futurepop on:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt

It's actually got quite a cult following of real artists and industry figures, who genuinely love Futurepop, and often return to stream it for inspiration, telling us it's "full of bangers they wish they'd written" and that's definitely our vision for the playlist, which is why we're so picky with its curation. Some of the most wildly popular artists on that playlist who are huge inspirations, have actually had their reps contact us to submit to Futurepop, which is the ultimate compliment.

Your Body is ridiculously catchy, and full of innovative production all over the place, which keeps it interesting. That flume-esque wonky bassline in the drop was great. The feature, by Jae, was on point, with great bars and a great flow. The darkness of the beat heavily reminded us of a track called U Talkin' To Me by Disco Montego (look them up) however, what made this different is that it refused to be a throwback, retro track at all. It effectively discarded the tropes that could've so easily pulled this into a dark discopop.80s synthwave vibe. The moment that sealed the deal for us, were the introduction of the rapid high synth sequence around 2:07. Love the track, honestly. We're very happy to say we've added you to the playlist, on both Apple Music, and Spotify. You made it look easy, but we actually have to turn away an enormous amount of music, plus, we never have over 50 tracks on the playlist. We're extremely selective, and you're among some serious A-list peers.

Here's a couple of things to note about being added:

Futurepop is a passion project. We're consciously keeping it fresh, keeping it one of the most AAA quality playlists known in the industry; only 40-50 tracks max. We hunt for artists that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design, atypical arrangements, informed by hip-hop and pioneering alternative R&B, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. This makes the playlist a magnet for aspiring artists, who return to stream it regularly for inspiration. You'll hear what we mean if you play through a few of the artists we're currently featuring. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I'd definitely encourage you to follow it if this is your jam. One tip: if you can get your fanbase streaming Futurepop while you're on it, we have found it has an incredible impact on populating your "Fans Also Like" section.

One other thing I can offer you, is an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, we put the playlist on his artist account. Now that you're part of the Futurepop club, I really recommend you capitalise on this and connect! If you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and tell him you were added by Paige. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. You should get some good value out of talking to him and letting him know you've joined the Futurepop ranks. You seem like like-minded artists who value building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige
GNH Records¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†

Dear Sergio Alejandro,

First of all I really liked the fact that you had the English subs in the video !!! Very clever move !

Although "Pensando En Ti" is a very solid production, there were a couple of things that I would have liked differently; if I may :

a) At 1:38 I was really expecting the kick and snare to have being introduced !
b) Drums were a bit in the back in the mix. Also, I would have really liked for a way bigger low end, especially for a song of your genre ! When I compared your songs against similar songs in my playlists, the difference was more obvious than I would like for my listeners.
(One great trick here is to compare your mix against the great ones, and notice how the drums sound on different sound systems !)

Not a bad song at all, but unfortunately at this level the smallest differences can have the greatest impacts.

I'm really sorry I will have to pass on this gem for now Sergio Alejandro.

Can't but thank you for your submission and wish you all the success in 2021 !

Thanks for your submission. We listened to your track carefully this morning. Indeed it's well composed and arranged (theme, instruments etc) BUT the mix could be enhance if you use more of good reverbs and compressor so as to "glue" all instruments together. Use panning as well. Especially strings lack of reverb in the first part of the track, and ideally the arpeggio shouldn't not make the string pattern sounds too repetitive (fix the velocity, try too make it sounds more "natural", not programmed strings). It's not easy to make samples sounds real and natural the play one's play it but it's important in order to make your track sounding best, not "out of the box" (samples). All the best

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Swallow to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Swallow and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
Haunting and etheral are two words that quickly came to mind here. You've got a very atmospheric vocal delivery, the vocal performance here was absolutely lovely to listen to and holds our attention around those reversed-synth countermelodic notes. The little high bells and choice of chords (chromatic) definitely gives this whole track an unsettling, Phantom Of The Opera feel, but with a nice modern twist.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, I can't really confidently call this a strong pop song. This is very avant garde, for sure. It flirts with the pop genre but it's definitely something more artistic and abrasive. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on avant garde, or potentially art pop, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

hey there guys, thanks for sharing your music! This is a kickass alt rock tune with the electro elements mixed in. Reminds me of Linkin Park a bit when it comes to the overall sound. Hey there! Massive sounding here! Very neat instrumental patterns that mix in great with the edgy vocals! But for now we're looking for a more commercial kind of rock track. Thanks so much for sharing! All the best!

Hi guys. Firstly thanks for sending me your music. I really appreciate it.
Electro-rock with dashes of rap and post-hardcore. Does it work? I actually think it kind of does. It is certainly different and it has a stadium anthem feel to it.
I have a couple of issues though. When singing in your second language, you really need to get the lyrics right, not just with the grammar, but with the pronunciation too. Because when you have a very lyric heavy track like this one all the little things add up.
I think this really stands up as it's really a bridge between electronic and hard-core rock. There's definitely not many acts around producing this type of sound. In my mind I start to think of Alice Cooper and Black Sabbath, bringing them into the 21st century. We're not really allowed to talk about these guys any more but Lostprophets are a decent example of where they were trying to go with their sound.
The production is first rate. Obviously there are so many levels you are playing with here and the balance is just right. I commend you on that!
This is definitely a contender to get onto the rock stations playlists. it has something about it that makes it stand out. I will definitely pass your links onto our programming manager and see what they want to do with the track.
I wish you all the success with the release and look forward to hearing more from you guys very soon. Cheers, Beefy

Till We Die levitates somewhere between late-eighties nu-metal,  alternative rock, indie rock, and contemporary alt-metal. The song combines all these elements in such a distinctive composition, but these ingredients work together in harmony. Perhaps the easiest way to explain this song is to classify verse into a nu-metal/hip hop metal category, while the half-step choruses are leaning towards alt-metal/alt-rock. The group also incorporates a bit of electronic music along the way. However, these are mainly minimal but hearable accentuations that decorate specific partitions of the song. Till Will Die has a strong potential for commercial success because of the ear-appealing choruses that are remaining memorable. Good job!

Hi¬†Maevane :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting La Mome to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to La Mome and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
While we do not speak French, we appreciated the beauty in this track. Your feminine, bedroom-vocal delivery was obviously remeniscent of acts like Lorde, Billie Eilish and so on, and the slowjam, chilled bedroom pop vibe was given an extra accent with those synth sweeps throughout the choruses. This seems to be a lyric-heavy singer-songwriter track that sounds like it's very personal and drawn from real-life experiences, it comes across effectively in both the piano-driven arrangement and your careful vocal emotion.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, this wasn't really that different from the regular bedroom pop female pop formula in a way that makes it appropriate for our playlist. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

What an unusual track. The writer obviously has a sense of humour that permeates the song. Quirky, comedic lyrics combine with a persistent rock beat as a music bed. The music video is most entertaining with its numerous pop culture icons and symbolic references. A genuine 'novelty' number.

I do wish you all the best for 2021, keep being you.

Hey Naftali, thanks for the submission. So I didn't hear any incorporation of reggae vibes in your new track 'waves of faith' for starters. Your track has much work that needs done in the progression department, meaning the flow of the track wasn't as smooth as it could be. Much of this stems from your vocals such as when you try to put a lot out in the hooks and your pace begins to out weighs the melody in speed. Synchronicity is key, it's so important to match the tempo tie between vocals and melody. Also the video didn't make much sense, it did more harm than good for your track. The parts of the vocalist singing were inspirational but the man in the woods almost seemed comedic at times. For a production that was supposed to bare meaning, the man in the woods 'struggling to survive' whom had a civilization literally right next door, took away from the meaning. The acting in and of itself was lack luster. Overall decent production quality song wise but there is much work that needs to be done. Hope this helps, keep on fighting to be heard! -Affinity Ascension

Hello again!

What a blast, guys! This track is a bomb and it absolutely blew my mind! I loved the Progressive House beat with some Techno elements, it really took the song to a deeper level of darkness and this atmosphere fits the vocals perfectly.

I liked the lyrics so much and those deep vocals gave it an extra depth of emotion, it sounds absolutely addicting. I've already listened to the song four times in a row by now and it just keeps getting better and better, much due to the vocals.

The instrumental really amazed me, it has a very dark vibe (reminded me of Township Rebellion), strong and groovy beats, a Progressive House structure and it flirts very closely with Techno too. All that mixed together just turned into a beautiful combination that made this song sound like a majestic wall of sound.

As a Deep/Progressive House fan myself, I liked "Deep Into Your Soul", but I'm completely shook by the sound you guys achieved with "The Fall", this is a masterpiece, no doubt!

I'll be very happy to share this song with my team and on our Twitter, as well as add it on our Spotify playlist soon as it gets available.

Thanks for sending the track, be safe and keep on!

Tech x Techno x Deep Melodic vibes. Interesting elements. The high hats are a bit too present, we don't hear the rest of the song/bass line during the drop. Scrolling through the song we have the same feeling, the same elements playing. The higher synth which copies the bass line is high pitched so makes it crowded (watch EQ) and is not necessary - let the bass line do the main job. Use the top layer for something else.

Keep sending new music

Hi Alain. Firstly, thank you for letting me hear you music. I really appreciate it. However I must say I'm not exactly sure what you want feedback on. Electro-Jazz is definitely not my scene.
Is this a single? an album track? or a submission for background music for a movie or computer game? Personally I don't see any value in this as a standalone piece. 
If you're putting out some examples of your talent as a music creator then this is great, but commercially there is very little that anyone can do with it, with a view to radio airplay. I don't think even the jazz specific shows would give this a go.
I have to stress that my experience of this genre and type of music is very limited, but I have been involved with a station here that used to have a jazz show, and I am positive that this just wouldn't be a consideration.
I do apologise if I seem a bit harsh, but as I mentioned, I',m not 100% sure what you want me to tell you.
However, I do wish you all the best and do hope that your music does get picked up in some format.
All the best, Beefy

Ciao Danilo! Grazie per la tua submission. Ho ascoltato con attenzione e interesse il tuo pezzo. In me hai rievocato alcuni racconti di Zerocalcare e la cosa mi √® piaciuta tantissimo.

Entrando nello specifico del tuo lavoro:

- Arrangiamento e Composizione: 
Il timing di 3:38 √® coerente con le logiche pi√π moderne dell'industria musicale, sopratutto nel mercato italiano in cui la tendenza a stare sotto i 4 minuti sta prendendo piede. 
L'arrangiamento √® interessante e si lascia ascoltare con leggerezza. Tuttavia sento la mancanza di una vera e propria progressione strumentale e dinamica, che porti l'ascoltatore verso l'ultima strofa. Intendo elementi che si aggiungono man mano in modo da creare stratificazioni sonore sempre pi√π ricche.

- Produzione: 
Il testo √® molto bello, vissuto, sincero e il tuo modo di cantare, quasi disinteressato, rende tutto autentico. Mi piacciono molto le tue voci in risposta a quella lead. Ci sono solo alcuni punti in cui sistemerei il timing della voce perch√® sembra che vada leggermente fuori tempo. Da "e nun se ricorda mai" c'√® qualcosa che non va tra il timing della voce, lo shaker e il "palm mute" della chitarra. Verifica l'autotune o il melodine sui ritornelli perch√® sento qualche oscillazione strana sulle linee vocali lead. Sulla produzione della strumentale mi piace l'intreccio delle chitarre e degli ambienti (riverberi) in cui le hai inserite. L'unica nota dolente √® il drumkit che a mio parere non √® molto coerente con il mood del pezzo. Inoltre la sua struttura ritmica accentua la mancanza di quelle variazioni dinamiche di cui ti parlavo prima. Ho capito l'intento della batteria elettronica ma non credo sia funzionale al pezzo.

- Mix e Master: 
Le tue voci sono ben bilanciate e intelligibili in ogni punto. Buona l'immagine stereofonica. Il master mi sembra molto gentile e rispettoso del materiale sonoro. Non √® stato distruttivo e ti assicuro che questo oggi √® davvero molto raro.

IL PEZZO MI PIACE UNA CIFRA!

Les images du clip qui l'accompagne propulse les songes dans une univers onirique, avec son atmosph√®re qui se r√©sume en une sorte de r√™ve √©veill√©.

Ciao Cristian! Grazie per la tua submission. Ho ascoltato con attenzione e interesse il tuo pezzo. E‚Äô stato interessante ascoltare questo accostamento di Retro Wave ad un testo cantato in italiano. 

Entrando nello specifico del tuo lavoro:

- Arrangiamento e Composizione: 
Molto interesante il testo. Si percepisce qualcosa di autobiografico e questo rende tutto pi√π autentico. Da un punto di vista armonico √® molto coerente con il modo Italiano degli anni ‚Äô90. Le strofe tengono bene il confronto con i chorus in cui l‚Äôesplosione dinamica e armonica creano un‚Äôottima diversificazione. 

- Produzione: 
Molto interessanti i suoni che hai utilizzato. E‚Äô tutto molto coerente con la Retro Wave. Il drumkit e il synth Bass offrono il giusto supporto a tutta la struttura. L‚Äôintervento dei fraseggi ritmici della chitarra elettrica √® molto interessante e ADORO l‚Äôarpeggiatore che hai inserito nei Chorus. L‚Äôunica cosa cosa che avrei cambiato √® il bridge. In quel momento avrei cercato soluzioni dinamiche pi√π morbide e distese per dare maggiore enfasi all‚Äôultimo chorus. In alcuni punti √® troppo evidente l‚Äôuso dell‚Äôautotune che, a mio parere non √® molto coerente con il mood del brano.

- Mix e Master: 
Il mix mi sembra un po scuro, cupo. Manca di aria nella parte alta dello spettro e questo riduce fortemente la percezione dell‚Äôimmagine stereofonica. Anche la voce √® troppo scura. Probabilmente sulla voce avrei utilizzato una leggera saturazione armonica per dargli aria e respiro. 
Il master √® gentile e non esasperato nelle pressioni sonore (questo √® un bene).

Il pezzo spacca! Continua cos√¨ ma fai molta attenzione alla parte di post produzione e mixing. E‚Äô proprio l√¨ che un pezzo ben prodotto pu√≤ diventare una potenziale HIT.

Hi¬†Lavara :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting It's Time To, to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to It's Time To, and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
Opening and grounding the track with that 6 note piano arpeggio loop was great, and once the track and verse established itself, taking it away for the pre-chorus was great, it effectively gave some contrast before the main "get low get low" refrain.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, I don't feel that in this instance the vocal performance was doing it for me. Not that it's a bad performance, it's just that I wasn't really drawn in by a strong earworm pop chorus, it kind of fell away into the territory of an alternative hip-hop, alternative R&B track, without all that much experimental pop flavour seeping through. It's a hard thing to articulate, but essentially this was a FINE alternative R&B/hiphop example, but not quite there as a Futurepop genre track. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop/hiphop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hi Sam! Thanks for your submission. 
I listened to your song very carefully and it brought back to my memory some Daughtry‚Äôs Song. Your voice is mature and structured. Very Good! 

Talking about your song I'll try to be clear.

- Arrangement and Composition:
The harmonic structure is very interesting and sticks very well with the text. I feel a nice nostalgic mood. The pre-chorus is built very well and offers good supports to the chorus

- Production:
The production is good, simple and strong. Personally, I missed a climax moment. A chorus with a blast of drums, bass, and electric guitars but this is only a personal opinion. I understand what your musical intention was. 
I would like to point out the song "what hurts the most" by Rascal Flatts. In this song, you can listen to the structure and the evolutions in the rhythmic and harmonic layers.

- Mix and Master: 
The mix and master are very good, smooth, and clear.

I hope you enjoy my point of view.

Hi¬†Knafo :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Key For A Stranger to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Key for a Stranger, and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
I thought the minimal, held back nature of the percussion here worked really well. It allowed your vocal to build the emotion of the track, underscored beautifully by that keyboard performance. This is a track for afterparties, for drinking whisky, for late night highway drives, for contemplation and introspection. It is an exceptional track and I commend you for the world you built around this with such synthetic sound design slowly evolving by the 2nd-3rd minute.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, this is much too chilled electronic, contemplative, introspective indieelectronic for our playlist. However, I know that this will work for more introspective playlists. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on chilled, indie electronic acts, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link (Spotify). Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections. I think he'll love this song.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hello again PYRONIA! Thanks for sending us Watching The Storm. Just like your last submission, Miss Music, here your groove and dancefloor appeal here was once again fantastic. However, much the same reasoning for our knock-back applies: This just wasn't a pop track for us. Just like Miss Music, this has large expanses of instrumental that work for an electronic/dancefloor number, but as for a pop track, felt underdeveloped and lonely between the vocal parts. If you're going for an indie dance track that doesn't rely on huge pop topline choruses, then this is a success. But it's not a Futurepop track, sadly.

As I said last time though, I would encourage you to contact our managed artist (and co-curator of several playlists) Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) While I can't offer you a placement on Futurepop, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then introduce yourself to him. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and if you're a social type, it's valuable to be connected. I'll leave it with you. Go for it, and all the best!

Paige

Hi¬†WAN :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting About U to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to About U and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
The detail you've put into perfecting those vocal chop points for that drop is just great! It really shows in how the phrasing dances with that synthesized sequence. The percussion comes in and completes the groove, with a huge syncopation that pays off really well. This is a great single for the dancefloor, it's really difficult not to get moving during this thing.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, this is definitely more of an EDM/electronic track than it is a pop song. We tend to avoid high tempo club tracks on our playlist. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Such an interesting psych-pop/indie rock tune that vividly resembles the late nineties alternative rock era. The number includes high-pitched thematic, which resonates with confident synth tones. The arrpegiated guitar chord progressions are entirely submerged beneath this theme, but they're hearable enough. These arrpegios are becoming full-struming bare chords that are serving as a powerful background during the choruses. Semi-distorted basslines are supporting these chords with a layer of low-end tones that are acting like a compound between guitars and completely stable rhythm section. The synth theme is may sound repetitious and annoying because of the high notes. The chorus should be  less repeated as well, but it doesn't spoil all the fun. Now Your Life's Gone resembles the music of Beck, Kula Shaker, but it can also compared with a  lot of contemporary indie rock acts.

Hi¬†Julian :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Strangers to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Strangers and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
With that dancefloor tempo, and your euphoric, strong female vocal lead, this has all the markings of mainstream electropop success. There's tonnes to love about Strangers, from that Royksopp-style bassline to those resonating synth countermelodies hard sidechained to the kick, and those low-formant warped backing vocal accents.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, this isn't the style of music we tend to feature on Futurepop. While this would definitely be among singles for playlists like Cloudkid, MrSuicidesheep and countless others, the uptempo electropop/dancepop genre is something we don't really look for here. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop + hiphop/r&b fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean, the tempo is much slower for one. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on the aforementioned more uptempo edmPop singles, though.¬†This truly was a great listen even though it's not a fit.

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hi¬†VENUS BLEEDS :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting DOLOROSA to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Dolorosa and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
The envelope automation on that raspy synth pad, accented by those sequenced synth drop notes, reminded us of producers like The Last Atlant and Seagram Murals. Both great talents, so huge compliments. This track was dark, brooding, oppressive. When that chorus vocal hit and you changed up your vocal delivery, adding vocoder layers, it really popped. A truly interesting track that held our attention.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, I thought this was more avant-garde, quite alternative, and quite dark. It's subjective, but this, to me, belongs in some incredibly cinematic, avant-garde indie electronic playlists. Not so much a playlist looking for pop songs. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, which DOLOROSA definitely does, but the thing we also want is the track to be grounded by very strong accessible pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you may hear what we mean. It was a tough one, though. We still very much enjoyed this, but for different reasons. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hi¬†OTR :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Pulse to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Pulse and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
It was immediately apparent this was going to be a classic, retro-flavoured live funk number, and when your vocal kicked in, we were strongly reminded of bands like The Whitest Boy Alive, which I hope you take as a huge compliment. This was strongly full of groove, despite its slow tempo, and those whistly synths actually reminded us of early Jamiroquai a little bit, too.

All that said, the unfortunate truth is none of the above is what we look for on our playlist. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on funk, indiepop, classic/retrowave synthpop, and so on, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Dear Kane & Joel,

I have to admit "Flying Form" is one of the most feeling-good songs I've heard in a while !
However, there were a few things I would have liked differently; if I may :

a) Vocals felt a bit too detached from the rest of the mix. Not sure if it was because of the mic used or the reverb/delay being different than the one used in the instrumental.
b) Instrumental was a bit too low in volume. I would have really liked it louder !
c) Last but not least, I would have really liked for a more compressed vocal, as at times the volume was fluctuating a bit more than I'd like.

With all these being said, I'm really really sorry I will have to pass on this gem for now.
Can't but thank you for your submission and wish you all the success in 2021 !

TR! C's new song "1989" begins by recalling Pink Floyd's classic "Another Brick In The Wall", a hit in the 80's and which inspires the musician. The song evolves into beats and vocal elements that flirt with reggae and Caribbean beats. The combination of different styles creates a rich and original song.

Hey TR!C,

First of all, I've got to say that I'm in love with this tune, stunning and very creative production. And even tho I think the vocals on the verses could've used a little bit more energy and clarity, 'cause it's kinda tricky to understand it sometimes, I absolutely loved every bit of it and I want to write more about it on my page and social media.

There's just some things I'd like you to answer and some things that I think would be great to have:

I'd love to hear more about you, your background and carrer, your inspirations and influences, your thought process behind 1989 and the album and if there's anything planned for you to release soon, may that be another EP, single or album.

I'd love if you could send me the album cover as well and some photos of yourself (if you want to, of course).

I hope we can make this work, I find your music really really good, some of the best and most creative that I have received on Groover.

High regards!

If you want to, you can contact me here or at pareadoblog@gmail.com

Salut, 

Vraiment bien le son, le clip, l'√©nergie, la vibe, l'univers. Bien jou√©! T'as commenc√© quand la musique ? 

Juste un petit d√©tail, parfois des l√©gers offbeat qui me derange un peu au d√©but mais dans l'ensemble c'est clean. C'est bien produit. Le flow non chaland avec une voix un peu us√© ca apporte un truc.

Maintenant j'ai envi de te dire que c'est plus qualitatif que beaucoup de rappeurs qui pr√©tendent √™tre exp√©riment√©. Il y a moyen que ca fasse un r√©sultat. 

Pour ca il faudra que tu mettes en place un bonne promo. Ne penses pas label, contrat, signature, tu n'en a pas besoin pour le moment. 

Si tu as une petite √©quipe avec un peu d'imagination et quelques comp√©tence, tu peux t'en sortir. 

Voila quelques conseils pour gagner en visibilit√©:

- Freestyle sur IG et Tiktok
- Concours de Rap (1minute2 rap...)
- Publicit√© payante sur les r√©seaux sociaux: Fb, Snap, IG... 
- Envoyer au media (via groover ou en direct)
- Faire tourner dans ton quartier ou ta ville en disant aux gens de faire tourner. Ca a l'air b√™te comme √ßa mais si 10 personnes font tourner a 10 qui font tourner a 10 et ainsi de suite... 

Bref, il y a pas mal d'id√©es √† exploiter pour peu de budget... 

Je te conseil de la jouer en ind√©, sortir plus de musique jusqu'a temps qu'un label, manager, distrib ou autre te d√©marche. Tu seras en position de n√©gocier car ce seront eux qui te voudront et pas l'inverse. 

Taff intelligemment et sois patient.

Si tu as des questions, n'h√©sites pas. Si tu as besoin de prod, on en parle. 

Dis moi si c'est sorti, je l'ajouterais √† une playlist.


Peace.

Hi¬†Antipop Mvmt :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting both So Lovely and No Boys Allowed to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, and you've sent us two to consider together at the same time, so we've taken a very close listen to both So Lovely as well as No Boys Allowed, and want to provide you this constructive feedback on both your submissions, together. So this is going to be twice as long, but we'll be copying the text into both tracks after giving them several close listens.
¬†
So Lovely has a strong, Taylor Swiftian vocal, it's remarkable. The delivery, the octave jumps in the topline... it's actually quite impressive how much this sounds like it could come from Lover. But the production obviously differs, this is no Jack Antonoff production and it doesn't really want to be. It carves its own path with more festival-EDM inspired futurebass drops and "yeah-yeah-yeah!" samples dropped in for good measure. I think it does this whole thing quite well, I could see crowds getting down to the postchorus drops. It's fully a mainstream pleaser.

No Boys Allowed is much the same in that your strong Taylor influence really shines through, again reminding us perhaps of something more from her Red era. I think this is fantastic, but at the same time, I wouldn't mind hearing some more of your own personal identity carved in here, more risk taking and less derivitive. The lyrics are so relatable and general they're bound to resonate with SO many people, but at the expense of your own most vulnerable parts of the story. I think this song is as strong as So Lovely, and you're bound to be added by every second pop playlist on DailyPlaylists for example... but personally, we'd love to get more inside YOUR head. You're so pop for an act that calls themselves Antipop Mvmt, I think you have leagues more risks you can take and still not risk alienating your target audience. :) 

So ultimately, while both songs impressed us immensely, this is simply much too mainstream for what we look for. Neither single subverts the expectations away from "regular" commercially successful sweet pop. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks, with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, interesting lyrics, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. It's a very hard thing to pull off, and even harder to describe in words. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hi¬†Kiara :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Never to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Never and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
While this started rather classically as a soulful R&B single, the addition of that large sub and mid-bass helped to elevate this a little beyond throwback R&B territory and more into synthpop territory. It definitely ticks that crossover-genre box, and it does it really effectively. The retro flavours are still abundant, with the repetitious "wowow" synth fills and tape-delayed low-fi warbled synthwork underlaying the rest of the instrumentation. It was a fantastic track, and that sultry, breathy vocal really tied it all together.

Ultimately, while it impressed us, "Never" just didn't subvert the expectations away from retro-flavoured synthpop/R&B enough to really make a statement that it wanted to sound like "the future" so much as it did past decades. For Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. It's a shame because we still truly enjoyed 'Never' very much, It's just that we try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop and retro sound design choices. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on this, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R

Thank you so much for sharing this as well! I think good production music for synchronization purposes threads a fine line between score and "listening" music. To me, this piece sounds more like it was a score in a film and got exported after the fact. Production music cues tend to be shorter, around 2:30min, and I believe they are usually more supportive than protagonistic, it has to have a purpose or intention, but not take away from the visuals or dictate the mood too much. To me, this piece's structure is too long, too dynamic, and it has a lot to say, I think it works for listening purposes, it's a fine composition to stand alone, for synch I think it's a bit dense. It'd be hard to pitch this particular cue to any trailer or advertising campaign I might be working on, with that said, I like the sound of the instruments, and arrangement as a song to listen to. I hope this is constructive. If the goal is to get synch licenses then study other libraries to get inspired. Good luck!

Hello Andrei, thanks for reaching me!
I really would have liked the track to be contextualized to better understand its focus, if it is a sound tracks, first EP, latest single, or whatever.
Really spicy track! At first impression I felt the first part (up to 1:27) was hard to get into it. On a second listen instead, knowing better your style, everything was more "suitable". This might be a problem if you are looking to grow a fan base. The first seconds of the song is what hooks nowdays.
But I understand it's probably not a thing for this genre or this style of music, but still something to consider.
The middle part is really exciting, but in some points I felt the low end not well centered, wich can be good for the "piano wide feeling", but generally really wierd with the subkick or the bass. Be sure to check the low end balance (talking about pan, not volume) in mix and master phases.
I really like the space you created around the piano.
I would find some percussions (cymbals, rattles, sand tubes, shakers etc.) to add textures in the more slow parts and to help the build up in the parts with more movement. I'm not talking about a perpetual beat, but just some texture around to keep the ears surprised.

I hope I helped and made clear all my ideas.
Cheers,
Lorenzo

Hello A.P !

First of all thank you for contacting me.

So, i listened to your song; I liked it very much.
I sincerely find the quality of the production really good, it is deep as it should be for this style of music. The reverb of the piano and well dosed, you can easily distinguish all the elements so the mix is good. Everything sounds crystal clear, the violins are very beautiful as well. The only thing missing may be a bit of power is the rhythm part (drums and percussion), but since the piece is melodic and calm you certainly did it express. It's a rich and cinematic piece like I like, bravo, for me it's ok. 
You can release it in digital platforms without any problem.
Don't hesitate to come back to me when it's on spotify and I'll add it in one of my playlist.

Have a good continuation!

Pierre

Hello guys, thank you for sending us your remix. The Introduction is good; I don't like so much the voice (but I suppose this voice is in the original version too). I like the progression from 1 minute: it is very deep and powerful. I like how the track evolves. The track sounds like the Afterlife, Maceo Plex or Kompakt staff, is very contemporary. It could work in a festival or i a club: it is a perfect banger. I love the piano roll at 3.20 minute, it is a perfect stop, oniric and methaphysic (very, very good choise). From 5 minutes to the end is pure gold and i love the "tribal touch". This is not my fauvorite style of techno music but this track is very brillant, i can perfectly dance and enjoy it in a party. Thank you so much guy, good luck and well done.

Hi Romain,
thank you for sharing your song "Tout Ce Que J‚Äôaime" with us and for letting us know you. Your music seems absolutely well produced and has its own commercial potential. Having marked your message with the initials "Exclu" and having made a specific request (radio programming), it does not seem appropriate to share your material on our social networks for promotional purposes only. Hi Kipani, thanks for the track.

The music here is very bold, cinematic almost!

I do wonder though if it's drowning your voice out a little.  I think that's more of a production issue than your actual voice though.  I  do appreciate tracks that can build in the way you have done here, although it is more easy listening than anything I would ever listen to.

I don't doubt there is a market for this sound on daytime radio, probably in the US more than here in the UK.  Without a 'wave your hands in the air, screaming it out loud' type chorus the track, although bold to a point when compared to the pop smashes around in todays ultra competitive market is ultimately relatively tame.

Like I said the easy listening market is where I'm sure you find success and I wish you all the best for 2021.

Hi¬†Kane and Joel :)

My name is Paige, from GNH Records. Thank you so much for submitting Flying Form to us to consider for our Apple Music + Spotify playlist, Futurepop. It's our home for¬† "cutting-edge pop acts who nimbly genre-blend with clever, subversive sound design, ultramodern hip-hop or pioneering alternative R&B."¬†It has a rabid cult following which we're very proud of.

Here are the links to follow / share it:
- Spotify: urlgeni.us/spotify/NgzB¬†
- Apple Music: urlgeni.us/applemusic/7jUt¬†

I realise it's a valuable use of credits to do this here, so we've taken a very close listen to Flying Form and want to provide you this constructive feedback on your submission.
¬†
Flying Form is definitely calling us back to the 90s, when pop was more innocent, romance was the norm, and that oldskool style of dancepop paired with that obligatory hiphop "rap" verse was expected. This is one hundred percent a throwback, and it's not afraid to show it. Has it got appeal? Hell yeah. Is it a fun time? Hell yeah. 

That said, for Futurepop, we're consciously trying to be a real point of difference, looking for singles that push themselves into a bolder niche, taking innovative risks with more synthetic sound design or atypical arrangements, while still being grounded by very strong pop fundamentals. And most crucially, nothing about it has to be retro, or hint of throwbacks to styles of previous decades in an obvious fashion. Flying Form just cannot confidently be called "the future of pop" when it sounds like it could've smashed it in the charts even 30 years ago. Not to say this was a bad song by any measure, in fact it's almost certain to have an audience. However, as a fit for Futurepop, it's a miss. When you play through the first few artists we've selected for the playlist, you'll hear what we mean. We try to elevate the playlist beyond systemic commercial R&B/pop. I think you will easily find some major success with playlists and blogs that do focus on more broad pop, though.¬† ¬†

One other thing I can offer you, is a bit of an industry connection. One of our managed artists is Spectoral (@spectoral on Instagram) who co-curates the playlist with us. In fact, it lives on his artist account. So while I can't offer you a placement on the playlist, if you're an artist who is interested in creating music for the bleeding-edge, an artist who is a music addict like us, who shares our tastes, and always aspires to keep tabs on the most current sounds, then I'd strongly encourage you to DM @spectoral - on Instagram. Introduce yourself to him and send him your link. Tell him you spoke to Paige on Groover. He's real nice, a well connected producer and curator from Australia who is a true passionate new music addict himself. He's also a committee member of a not-for-profit (free) organisation called Beat Collective (beatcollective.net) that is one of the biggest artist-producer communities in the world. So he meets a LOT of artists and it's very valuable to be connected. So even if that doesn't result in you getting added to a playlist, you should still get some good value out of at least talking to him, a like-minded artist who values building good industry connections.

Go for it! :)

Paige R
GNH

Hey, Little Gigi! It is refreshing to see new independent artists like you springing up :) In general, "quarantine romance" sounds very good, the song offers dynamic movements and we can clearly perceive different textures in the parts and the refrains, which is good, because it makes the song easy to assimilate. If I could give you one piece of advice, it would be to work a little more on your pronunciation, since you're singing in English, try and make sure you revise the sounds of the words and the linking sounds when you connect one or more words, so that your vocals can sound even more natural. Overall, the lyrics are quite personal and I'm sure lots of people will relate and identify with your song. Keep up with the good work!

Hi Jevil Project! Thanks for your submission. 
I listened to your song very carefully. The musical direction is clear but I think the mixing and mastering did not enhance your work.

Talking about your song I'll try to be clear, let's go step by step.

- Arrangement and Composition:
The harmonic structure is very interesting. I feel a nice aggressive mood. At 00:18 a bad cut is very evident. Sometimes the electric guitar on the right is not in time. I listen some not accurate fade out of the guitars tracks (for example at 00:48).

- Production:
The production is the weak point of the song. Personally I missed a climax moment and a succession of different dynamics moment. The guitars are layered in a bad way and often are confused. The drum kit sounds too far and the kick is covered by some bass and guitars frequencies. All sounds are confused and ‚Äúcloudy‚Äù.

- Mix and Master: 
I think the mix is incorrect in this song. The stereo image is closed and all instruments sounds muddy and gloomy.

I am sure that with the right producer your sound will improve!

Ciao Don Crescenzio! Grazie per la tua submission. Ho ascoltato con attenzione e interesse il tuo pezzo. Il contrasto della tua figura con quello che canti √® assolutamente pazzesco. Sei stato bravo a suscitare in me una sana curiosit√†. Il tuo background musicale √® un bagaglio importante anche se espresso in un genere molto diverso da quello su cui hai lavorato per anni con il tuo violino.

Entrando nello specifico del tuo lavoro:

- Arrangiamento e Composizione: 
Il timing di 2:33 √® perfetto considerato il genere e le nuove tendenze del mercato. Molto interessante il testo, √® autentico e scritto molto bene. Le scelte armoniche sono semplici ed efficaci ma credo che con la tua preparazione potresti inserire elementi pi√π ricercati e distinguerti in modo efficace dall‚Äôattuale panorama Trap/HipHop. 

- Produzione: 
Molto interessanti i suoni che hai utilizzato. Buono il flow, tutto molto a tempo e ben serrato sulle drums. E‚Äô tutto molto coerente con le nuove tendenze.  Forse manca, nella stesura della sezione ritmica, qualcosa che diversifichi in modo efficace la prima parte del pezzo dall‚Äôultimo chorus che, in questo caso, suona molto simile al precedente. 

- Mix e Master: 
Il mix mi sembra un po scuro. Manca di aria nella parte alta dello spettro. Anche la voce la trovo un po‚Äô scura e carente di armonici. Probabilmente sulla voce avrei utilizzato una leggera saturazione armonica per dargli aria e respiro. 
Il master √® gentile e non esasperato nelle pressioni sonore, sopratutto nel low end che risulta compatto e definito (questo √® un bene). 

Il pezzo spacca! Se posso darti un consiglio relativo alla tua immagine: cerca di concentrarti sul fatto che sei in violinista e ti stai facendo largo nel panorama HipHop. Fortifica l‚Äôimmagine del bravo ragazzo con il papillon perch√© crea un contrasto grottesco ed efficace con la tua musica.

La produzione √® tecnicamente molto buona e assolutamente nella media produttiva attuale, ma √® proprio la mancanza di un ‚Äúguizzo‚Äù di originalit√† nei suoni che rende la proposta eccessivamente allineata con il mercato, immaginiamo che si una scelta voluta ma ti consigliamo di cercare delle sonorit√† che ti rendano molto pi√π riconoscibile e originale.
